Source code for kafe.dataset

'''
This submodule defines a `Dataset` object, a container class for storing measurement data
and error data.

.. moduleauthor:: Daniel Savoiu <daniel.savoiu@ekp.kit.edu>
'''

from string import join, split

from fit import Fit
from numeric_tools import *     # automatically includes numpy as np

DEBUG_MODE = 1


[docs]def debug_print(message):
    if DEBUG_MODE:
        print message        
    


[docs]class Dataset: #(object):
    '''
    The `Dataset` object is a data structure for storing measurement and error data. In this implementation,
    the `Dataset` has the compulsory fields `xdata` and `ydata` which are used for storing the actual data,
    as well as fields related to a specific measurement error model. The `Dataset` object has fields such as
    correlated and uncorrelated errors of the measurements. All error-related fields can be compiled into a
    single I{covariance matrix} (I{error matrix}). Error types supported by the `Dataset` object are:
        
        1. Statistical errors (fully uncorrelated errors), in the form of either
            - an array of individual x and/or y errors of each data point (error lists), or
            - a global uncorrelated/statistical error in x and/or y (global statistical error)
        2. Systematic errors. These are always fully correlated (global systematic error).
    
    or more than one of these combined. This is achieved by calculating a partial error matrix for each of these error
    types and adding all of these matrices together. A custom error matrix can also be provided, in which case all
    other error sources are ignored. This can be either a I{covariance} or a I{correlation} matrix.
    '''

    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        '''
        Construct the `Dataset`.
        
        Valid keyword arguments for this constuctor are:
        
            1. B{input_file}: This keyword argument should be a file object or the path to a file
               containing a plain-text represenatatio of the `Dataset`. For information on the
               structure of this file, see this class's X{get_formatted} method. If an B{input_file}
               is provided, all other input is ignored.
        
            2. B{xdata} and B{ydata}: If no input file is provided, these keyword arguments are
               B{compulsory} and are used to set the actual measurement data in the `Dataset`.
               They should be sequences of equal length containing floating point numbers. 
               Internally, these are converted to `NumPy` arrays.
        
            3. B{xcovmat} and/or B{ycovmat}: These should be `NumPy` matrix objects containing
               an error (covariance) matrix for the appropriate axis. If this argument is provided
               for an axis, all other error specifications are ignored.
        
            4. Any of 8 keywords corresponding to an error specification. These are composed of
                   - axis (B{x} or B{y}),
                   - error type (B{abs} or B{rel}), and
                   - correlation type (B{stat} or B{syst}), in that order. 
               For example, the keyword argument B{yrelsyst} sets a systematic (fully correlated) error
               of the entire data (global) and should be a floating point number. On
               the other hand, B{xabsstat} should be a list of statistical uncertainties
               in the direction of the I{x} axis, in the same order as the parent `Dataset`'s
               data. If only a number M{s} is given as a statistical error, an array of identical
               values M{s} is created and used as an error list.
               
            5. B{title}: This is the name of the given `Dataset`. If omitted, the `Dataset` will
                be given the generic name 'Untitled Dataset'.
               
            
               
        @keyword xdata: Measurement data I{x} values
        @type xdata: sequence of numeric values
        @keyword ydata: Measurement data I{y} values
        @type ydata: sequence of numeric values       
        
        @keyword xabsstat: Global absolute uncorrelated x-error or error list
        @type xabsstat: numeric value or sequence of numeric values
        @keyword yabsstat: Global absolute uncorrelated y-error or error list
        @type yabsstat: numeric value or sequence of numeric values
        @keyword xrelstat: Global relative uncorrelated x-error or error list
        @type xrelstat: numeric value or sequence of numeric values
        @keyword yrelstat: Global relative uncorrelated y-error or error list
        @type yrelstat: numeric value or sequence of numeric values
        
        @keyword xabssyst: Global relative correlated x-error
        @type xabssyst: numeric value
        @keyword yabssyst: Global relative correlated y-error
        @type yabssyst: numeric value
        @keyword xrelsyst: Global relative correlated x-error
        @type xrelsyst: numeric value
        @keyword yrelsyst: Global relative correlated y-error
        @type yrelsyst: numeric value
        
        @keyword xcovmat: Error matrix for x-axis
        @type xcovmat: numpy.matrix
        
        @keyword ycovmat: Error matrix for y-axis
        @type ycovmat: numpy.matrix
        
        @keyword input_file: File object or path to a file from which to read the `Dataset`
        @type input_file: file or string
        
        @keyword title: `Dataset` title.
        @type title: string
        '''
        
        # Definitions
        ##############
                   
        self.xdata = None           #:@ivar: Stores the I{x}-axis measurement data
        self.ydata = None           #:@ivar: Stores the I{y}-axis measurement data
        
        self.errors = {}
        '''an error dictionary containing all relevant errors
        its keys are the error specifications
        its values should be either numbers for systematic errors
        or NumPy arrays for statistical errors'''
        
        self.xcovmat = None         #:@ivar: Stores the covariance matrix for the I{x} axis 
        self.ycovmat = None         #:@ivar: Stores the covariance matrix for the I{y} axis
        
        if kwargs.has_key('title'):
            self.data_label = kwargs['title']
        else:
            self.data_label = 'Untitled Dataset'
            
        # Process keyword arguments
        #############################
        self.kwargs = kwargs        # store the keyword arguments in an instance variable so
                                    # they are accessible to methods later on

        if not self.read_from_file(): # first, try to read the Dataset from a file
            # if that didn't work
            for axis in ('x', 'y'):                     # go through the axes
                # load measurement data
                self.__load_data(axis)                  # load data for axis
                # load error data
                if self.__load_custom_cov_mats(axis):   # if loading of the custom error matrix succeeds
                    debug_print('Loaded custom error matrix for axis %s' % (axis,)) # print message
                else:                                   # if not, look for other errors
                    self.__load_other_errors(axis)      # and load them into the object
                    self.build_cov_mat(axis)            # construct the covariance matrix
                
    
    # Private methods
    ##################
    
    def __load_data(self, axis):
        '''
        Loads the `xdata` and `ydata` fields into the dataset.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to load data. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        '''
        
        if self.kwargs.has_key(axis+'data'):
            self.set_data(axis, self.kwargs[axis+'data'])
            return True
        else:
            # since data is compulsory, raise an error if no data is found
            raise Exception, "No measurement data provided for axis `%s'." % (axis,)
    
    def __load_custom_cov_mats(self, axis):
        '''
        Scans the keyword arguments passed to __init__ for a custom error matrix
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to check for an error matrix. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        @return: Returns `True` if loading the matrix succeeds, else returns `False`.
        '''
        
        if self.kwargs.has_key(axis+'covmat'):
            self.set_cov_mat(axis, self.kwargs[axis+'covmat'])
            return True
        else:
            self.set_cov_mat(axis, None)
            return False
    
    def __load_other_errors(self, axis):
        '''
        Scans the keyword arguments passed to __init__ for error specification.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to check for errors. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        '''
        
        for relativity in ('abs', 'rel'):               # go through all error types
            for correlation in ('stat', 'syst'):        # go through all correlation types
                if self.kwargs.has_key(axis+relativity+correlation): # check keywords for a certain error
                    self.set_error(axis+relativity+correlation, self.kwargs[axis+relativity+correlation]) # set the error
                else:
                    self.set_error(axis+relativity+correlation, None)
            
    
    def __check_integrity(self):
        '''
        Checks for inconsistencies in the `Dataset`, such as differing number of data points
        for different axes.
        
        @return: `False` if there are inconsistencies, else `True`
        '''
        
        if not len(self.get_data('x')) == len(self.get_data('y')):
            return False
        else:
            return True
    
    # Set methods
    ##############
    

[docs]    def set_data(self, axis, data):
        '''
        Set the measurement data for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to set the measurement data. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        @param data: Measurement data for axis.
        @type data: any iterable
        '''

        try:
            # check if the object is iterable (list or array)
            # by trying to get its iterator.
            iterator = iter(data)
        except TypeError:
            # if this fails, then this object is not iterable
            raise TypeError, "Error loading data for %s-axis. Expected iterable, got %s." % (axis, type(data))
        else:
            # if that succeeds, then this object is iterable
            if axis=='x':
                self.xdata = np.asarray(data) # cast the iterable to a numpy array
                self.size = len(self.xdata) # set the dataset's size
            elif axis=='y':
                self.ydata = np.asarray(data) # cast the iterable to a numpy array
            else:
                raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis %s." % (axis, )
    


[docs]    def set_cov_mat(self, axis, mat):
        '''
        Set the error matrix for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to load the error matrix. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        @param mat: Error matrix for the axis. Passing `None` unsets the error matrix. 
        @type mat: `numpy.matrix` or `None`
        '''
        
        if mat is not None:
            try:
                mat = np.asmatrix(mat) # try to cast argument to a matrix
            except:
                raise TypeError, "Cast to matrix failed. Object was of type `%s'" % (type(mat),)
        
            # allow even singular matrices for the time being
            ## the covariance matrix cannot be singular, so raise an error if that is the case
            #try:
            #    mat.I    # try to invert it
            #except:
            #    raise Exception, "Provided covariance matrix is singular."
        
        if axis=='x':
            self.xcovmat = mat
        elif axis=='y':
            self.ycovmat = mat
        else:
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis %s." % (axis, )
#         else:
#             raise TypeError, "Error loading error matrix for %s-axis. Expected None or numpy matrix object, got %s." % (axis, type(mat))



[docs]    def set_error(self, err_spec, err_val):
        '''
        Set the error with the specification `err_spec`:
            1. For statistical errors:
                - If `err_val` is a `NumPy` array, the error list is set to that
                - If `err_val` is a number, an error list with identical entries is generated 
                - If `err_val` is `None`, the error is unset 
            2. For systematic errors:
                - `err_val` should be a number and the error is set to that.
                - If `err_val` is `None`, the error is unset
        
        @param err_spec: Error specification. A string composed of axis (I{x} or I{y}), 
            error relativity specification (I{abs} or I{rel}) and error correlation type (I{stat} or I{syst}) 
        @type err_spec: string
        @param err_val: An error list (for statistical errors) or a float
        @type err_val: float or `numpy.array` or `None`
        '''
        
        if len(err_spec) != 8:       # check that the error specification has required length
            raise SyntaxError, "Cannot interpret error specification `%s'." % (err_spec,)
        
        # interpret the error specification
        axis = err_spec[0]          # extract the axis from the error specification
        relativity = err_spec[1:4]  # extract the relativity from the error spec.
        correlation = err_spec[4:]  # extract the correlation from the error spec.
        
        # check error specification for integrity
        if axis not in ('x', 'y'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis `%s'." % (axis, )
        if relativity not in ('abs', 'rel'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown relativity specification `%s'. Expected `abs' or `rel'." % (relativity, )
        if correlation not in ('stat', 'syst'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown correlation specification `%s'. Expected `stat' or `syst'." % (correlation, )
        
        
        # make sure errors are floats. Cast to float if necessary...
        if isinstance(err_val, np.ndarray) or isinstance(err_val, int):
            # cast err_val to a float
            err_val = 1.0 * err_val     
        
        # check if data type of err_val matches the error specification
        
        if err_val is not None: # further checking only relevant in err_val is NOT None
            if correlation == 'syst':
                # systematic errors should be floats
                if not isinstance(err_val, float):
                    # if not, raise error
                    raise SyntaxError, "Error setting systematic error `%s', expected number." % (err_spec,)
            elif correlation == 'stat':
                # statistical errors should be error lists
                if isinstance(err_val, float): # if a float value is given
                    # turn float value into array of identical values
                    err_val = np.ones(self.size) * err_val 
                elif not isinstance(err_val, np.ndarray): # else, if something other than an array is given, raise error
                    raise SyntaxError, "Error setting statistical error `%s', expected number or NumPy array." % (err_spec,)
        
        # set the relevant entry in the object's error dictionary
        self.errors.update({err_spec: err_val})
        
    
    # Get methods
    ##############



[docs]    def get_size(self):
        '''
        Get the size of the `Dataset`. This is equivalent to the length of `xdata`.
        '''
        
        if self.xdata is None:
            return 0
        else:
            return len(self.xdata)



[docs]    def get_data_span(self, axis, include_error_bars=False):
        '''
        Get the data span for an axis. The data span is a tuple (`min`, `max`) containing
        the smallest and highest coordinates for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to get the data span. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        
        @param include_error_bars: True if the returned span should be enlarged to
            contain the error bars of the smallest and largest datapoints (default: False)
        @type include_error_bars: boolean
        '''
        
        max_error_bar_size = 0. 
        min_error_bar_size = 0. 
        
        max_idx = tuple(self.get_data(axis)).index(max(self.get_data(axis)))   # get the index of the max datapoint
        min_idx = tuple(self.get_data(axis)).index(min(self.get_data(axis)))   # get the index of the min datapoint
        
        if include_error_bars:
            #try:
            max_error_bar_size = np.sqrt(self.get_cov_mat(axis)[max_idx, max_idx])  # get the error of the maximum datapoint
            min_error_bar_size = np.sqrt(self.get_cov_mat(axis)[min_idx, min_idx])  # get the error of the minimum datapoint
            #except:
            #    pass
        
        return [self.get_data(axis)[min_idx] - min_error_bar_size, self.get_data(axis)[max_idx] + max_error_bar_size]
        


[docs]    def get_data(self, axis):
        '''
        Get the measurement data for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to get the measurement data. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        '''
        
        if axis=='x':
            return self.xdata
        elif axis=='y':
            return self.ydata
        else:
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis %s." % (axis, )
        


[docs]    def get_error(self, err_spec):
        '''
        Returns the error value/array with the specification `err_spec`:
        
        @param err_spec: Error specification. A string composed of axis (I{x} or I{y}), 
            error relativity specification (I{abs} or I{rel}) and error correlation type (I{stat} or I{syst}) 
        @type err_spec: string
        '''
        if self.errors.has_key(err_spec):
            return self.errors[err_spec]
        else:
            raise IndexError, "Cannot get error with error specification `%s'" % (err_spec,)
        
    


[docs]    def get_cov_mat(self, axis):
        '''
        Get the error matrix for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to load the error matrix. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        '''
        
        if axis=='x':
            return self.xcovmat
        elif axis=='y':
            return self.ycovmat
        else:
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis %s." % (axis, )

    # Queries about error types
    


[docs]    def has_any_errors(self, axis):
        '''
        Returns `True` if at least an error type was provided for the axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to check for errors. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        
        @return: `True` if errors provided for axis, else `False`
        '''
        
        # make sure the axis specification is valid
        if axis not in ('x','y'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis `%s'" % (axis,)
        
        for err_spec in self.errors.keys():     # go through the error dictionary
            if err_spec[0] == axis:             # only look for keys corresponding to axis (first character)
                if self.errors[err_spec] is not None:   # when first item found which isn't None
                    return True                 # return immediately
        
        return False    # if nothing is found, return false
    


[docs]    def has_stat_errors(self, axis):
        '''
        Returns `True` if statistical errors were provided for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to check for errors. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        
        @return: `True` if statistical errors provided for axis, else `False`
        '''
        
        # make sure the axis specification is valid
        if axis not in ('x','y'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis `%s'" % (axis,)
        
        for err_spec in self.errors.keys():     # go through the error dictionary
            if err_spec[0] == axis:             # only look for keys corresponding to axis (first character)
                if err_spec[-4:] == 'stat':     # only look for statistical errors
                    if self.errors[err_spec] is not None:
                        return True                 # return immediately
        return False    # if nothing is found, return false
    


[docs]    def has_syst_errors(self, axis):
        '''
        Returns `True` if systematic (correlated) errors were provided for an axis.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to check for errors. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        
        @return: `True` if systematic errors provided for axis, else `False`
        '''
        
        # make sure the axis specification is valid
        if axis not in ('x','y'):
            raise SyntaxError, "Unknown axis `%s'" % (axis,)
        
        for err_spec in self.errors.keys():     # go through the error dictionary
            if err_spec[0] == axis:             # only look for keys corresponding to axis (first character)
                if err_spec[-4:] == 'syst':     # only look for systematic errors
                    if self.errors[err_spec] is not None:
                        return True                 # return immediately
        return False    # if nothing is found, return false
    


[docs]    def build_cov_mat(self, axis):
        '''
        Builds the error matrix for an axis from the error data. If a custom error matrix
        was already loaded, a warning message is printed and nothing is done.
        
        @param axis: Axis for which to construct the error matrix. Can be I{x} or I{y}.
        @type axis: string
        @return: `True` if building the error matrix succeeded, else `False`
        '''
        
        # take care not to overwrite custom error matrices
        if self.get_cov_mat(axis) is not None:
            print "Warning: Failed to construct error matrix for axis `%s'. Custom error matrix already loaded." % (axis,)
            return False
        
#         if not self.__check_integrity(): # before attempting construction, ensure the Dataset integrity
#             print "Warning: Failed to construct error matrix for axis `%s'. Dataset integrity check failed." % (axis,)
#             return False
        
        tmp_size = len(self.xdata)                                  # get the dataset's size
        tmp_matrix = np.asmatrix( np.zeros((tmp_size, tmp_size)) )    # construct a zero matrix
        
                
        for relativity in ('abs', 'rel'):               # go through all error types
            for correlation in ('stat', 'syst'):        # go through all correlation types
                tmp_err = self.get_error(axis+relativity+correlation)   # get the corresponding error
                if tmp_err is not None:                 # if error is defined... 
                    if correlation == 'stat':
                        if relativity == 'rel':             
                            tmp_err *= self.get_data(axis)  # relative errors need to be weighted with the actual data
                        tmp_matrix += np.asmatrix( np.eye(tmp_size) * tmp_err ** 2 ) # stat errors on diagonal
                    
                    elif correlation == 'syst':
                        if relativity == 'rel':
                            # for relative systematic errors, we first generate absolute systematic
                            # errors by multiplication with the measurement data
                            tmp_err *= self.get_data(axis)
                            
                            # the matrix to be added is then given by the outer (dyadic)
                            # product of this vector with itself
                            tmp_matrix += np.outer( tmp_err, tmp_err )
                             
                        else:            
                            tmp_matrix += np.asmatrix( np.ones((tmp_size, tmp_size)) * tmp_err ** 2 ) # syst errors everywhere
                    
                        
        self.set_cov_mat(axis, tmp_matrix)
    


[docs]    def get_formatted(self, format_string=".06e", delimiter='\t'):
        '''
        Returns the dataset in a plain-text format which is human-readable and
        can later be used as an input file for the creation of a new `Dataset`.
        
        The format is as follows::
        
            # x data
            x_1  sigma_x_1  
            x_2  sigma_x_2  cor_x_12
            ...  ...        ...       ...
            x_N  sigma_x_N  cor_x_1N  ...  cor_x_NN
            
            # y data
            y_1  sigma_y_1  
            y_2  sigma_y_2  cor_y_12
            ...  ...        ...       ...
            y_N  sigma_y_N  cor_y_1N  ...  cor_y_NN
        
        Here, the M{x_i} and M{y_i} represent the measurement data, the M{sigma_?_i} are the
        statistical uncertainties of each data point, and the M{cor_?_ij} are the correlation
        coefficients between the I{i}-th and I{j}-th data point.
        
        If the x or y errors are not correlated, then the entire correlation coefficient matrix
        can be omitted. If there are also no statistical uncertainties for an axis, the second
        column can also be omitted. A blank line is required at the end of each data block!
        
        @param format_string: A format string with which each entry will be rendered. Default is `.06e`, which means
            the numbers are represented in scientific notation with six significant digits.
        @type format_string : string
        @param delimiter: A delimiter used to separate columns in the output
        @type delimiter: string
        
        @return: A plain-text representation of the dataset.
        '''
        
        output_list = []
        
        # go through the axes
        for axis in ('x', 'y'):
            helper_list = []                                                # define a helper list which we will fill out
            stat_errs = extract_statistical_errors(self.get_cov_mat(axis))  # get the statistical errors of the data
            data = self.get_data(axis)
            cor_mat = cov_to_cor(self.get_cov_mat(axis))
            
            helper_list.append(['# %s data' % (axis,)])                     # add section title as a comment
            helper_list.append(['# datapoints'])                            # add a row for headings
            
            if self.has_stat_errors(axis):                              # if the dataset has stat errors
                helper_list[-1].append('stat. err.')                    # add a heading for second column
                if self.has_syst_errors(axis):                          # if there are also correlations (syst errors)
                    helper_list[-1].append('correlation coefficients')  # add a heading for the correlation matrix
            
            for idx in range(len(data)):
                helper_list.append([])                                              # append a new "row" to the helper list
                helper_list[-1].append( format(data[idx], format_string) )          # append the coordinate of the data point
                if self.has_stat_errors(axis):                                      # if the dataset has stat errors
                    helper_list[-1].append( format(stat_errs[idx], format_string) ) # append the stat error of the data point
                    if self.has_syst_errors(axis):                                  # if there are also correlations (syst errors)
                        for col in range(idx):                                                  # go through the columns of the correlation matrix
                            helper_list[-1].append( format(cor_mat[idx, col], format_string))   # append the correlation coefficients to the helper list
            
            helper_list.append([])  # append an empty list -> blank line
            output_list.append(helper_list)
            
            
        # turn the list into a string
        tmp_string = '' #
        for row in output_list:
            for entry in row:
                tmp_string += join(entry,delimiter) + '\n'
                
        return tmp_string
                    


[docs]    def write_formatted(self, file_path, format_string=".06e", delimiter='\t'):
        '''
        Writes the dataset to a plain-text file. For details on the format, see X{get_formatted}.
        
        
        @param file_path: Path of the file object to write. B{WARNING}: I{overwrites existing files}!
        @type file_path: string
        @param format_string: A format string with which each entry will be rendered. Default is `.06e`, which means
            the numbers are represented in scientific notation with six significant digits.
        @type format_string : string
        @param delimiter: A delimiter used to separate columns in the output
        @type delimiter: string
        
        @return: A plain-text representation of the dataset.
        '''
        
        # write the output of self.get_formatted to the file
        with open(file_path, 'w') as my_file:
            my_file.write(self.get_formatted(format_string))
            my_file.close()
                       


[docs]    def read_from_file(self):
        '''
        Reads the `Dataset` object from a file
        
        @return: True if the read succeeded, False if not
        '''
        
        # check if a file was provided as an input
        if not self.kwargs.has_key('input_file'):
            return False
        else:
            tmp_file = self.kwargs['input_file']    # store the keyword argument in a tmp variable
        
        try:
            tmp_lines = tmp_file.readlines()        # try to read the lines of the file
        except AttributeError:                      # this will fail if a file path string was passed, so alternatively:
            tmp_file = open(tmp_file, 'r')          # open the file pointed to by the path
            tmp_lines = tmp_file.readlines()        # and then read the lines of the file
            
        # Parse the file
        #################
            
        tmp_data = []       # append data progressively to this list 
        tmp_errors = []     # append error data progressively to this list
        tmp_cormat = []     # temporary storage of the correlation matrix
        
        axes = ('x', 'y')
        
        tmp_rownumber = 0   # keep track of the current (error matrix) row
        tmp_axis = 0        # keep track of the current axis (as an index in `axes')
        tmp_linenumber = 0  # keep track of the current line being read
        
        tmp_has_stat_errors = True # assume statistical errors
        tmp_has_syst_errors = True # assume correlations
        
        tmp_reading_data_block = False # don't assume that the file begins with a data block 
        
        for line in tmp_lines:                      # go through the lines of the file
            
            tmp_linenumber += 1                     # update the line number
            
            if '#' in line:
                line = split(line, '#')[0]          # ignore anything after a comment sign (#)
                
            if (not line) or (line.isspace()):      # if empty line encountered
                if tmp_reading_data_block:          # if currenty reading a data block, end reading it and commit data
                    
                    # Commit the parsed data to the object
                    #######################################
                    
                    self.set_data(axes[tmp_axis], tmp_data)                                     # commit measurement data
                    
                    if tmp_has_syst_errors: # if there is a correlation matrix
                        # Turn the lists into a lower triangle matrix
                        tmp_cormat = zero_pad_lower_triangle(tmp_cormat)
                    
                        # Symmetrize: copy the lower triangle to the upper half
                        tmp_cormat = make_symmetric_lower(tmp_cormat)
                    
                        self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], cor_to_cov(tmp_cormat, tmp_errors))    # commit covariance matrix
                        self.errors[axes[tmp_axis]+'absstat'] = np.asarray(tmp_errors)
                        self.errors[axes[tmp_axis]+'abssyst'] = True    # ugly, redo
                    elif tmp_has_stat_errors: # if there are just statistical errors
                        
                        self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], np.asmatrix(np.diag(tmp_errors)**2))   # commit covariance matrix
                        self.errors[axes[tmp_axis]+'absstat'] = np.asarray(tmp_errors)
                    else: # if there are no errors
                        self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], np.asmatrix(np.zeros((self.get_size(),self.get_size())))) # zero matrix                                  # commit covariance matrix
                        
                    # Reset temporary variables
                    #############################
                    
                    tmp_data = []       # append data progressively to this list 
                    tmp_errors = []     # append error data progressively to 
                    tmp_cormat = []     # temporary storage of the correlation matrix
                    tmp_has_stat_errors = True # assume statistical errors
                    tmp_has_syst_errors = True # assume correlations
                    tmp_rownumber = 0   # reset row number
                    tmp_axis += 1       # go to next axis
                    tmp_reading_data_block = False # end data block
                    
            else:  # else, if line is not empty, it must contain data
                
                if not tmp_reading_data_block:
                    tmp_reading_data_block = True       # attest that we are currently reading a data block  
                
                tmp_fields = split(line)                # get the entries on the line as a list (whitespace-delimited)
                
                if len(tmp_fields) == 1:        # if there is only one entry, we know it's just the measurement data
                    if tmp_has_stat_errors:
                        tmp_has_stat_errors = False # no stat errs for axis
                    if tmp_has_syst_errors:
                        tmp_has_syst_errors = False # no syst errs for axis
            
                tmp_data.append(float(tmp_fields[0]))   # first field is the coordinate of the data point
                
                if tmp_has_stat_errors:
                    tmp_errors.append(float(tmp_fields[1])) # second field is the error in that coordinate
                
                if tmp_has_syst_errors:                 # if there are correlations
                    tmp_cormat.append(map(float,tmp_fields[2:]) + [1.0])    # other fields are correlation coefficients (diagonal 1.0 added)
            
                if len(tmp_fields) != tmp_rownumber+2:  # if there are not enough entries for a valid correlation matrix
                    tmp_has_syst_errors = False         # attest that there is not a valid correlation matrix
                
                tmp_rownumber += 1                  # update row number
                
        # If parsing is complete, commit most recently gathered data
        
#         # Commit the parsed data to the object
#         #######################################
#         
#         self.set_data(axes[tmp_axis], tmp_data)                                     # commit measurement data
#         
#         if tmp_has_syst_errors: # if there is a correlation matrix
#             # Turn the lists into a lower triangle matrix
#             tmp_cormat = zero_pad_lower_triangle(tmp_cormat)
#         
#             # Symmetrize: copy the lower triangle to the upper half
#             tmp_cormat = make_symmetric_lower(tmp_cormat)
#         
#             self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], cor_to_cov(tmp_cormat, tmp_errors))    # commit covariance matrix
#         elif tmp_has_stat_errors: # if there are just statistical errors
#             
#             self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], np.asmatrix(np.diag(tmp_errors)**2))   # commit covariance matrix
#         else: # if there are no errors
#             self.set_cov_mat(axes[tmp_axis], None)                                  # commit covariance matrix
        
        return True
    


[docs]    def fit(self, fit_function, external_fcn=None, **kwargs):
        '''
        Fit the given function to the `Dataset`. Returns a `Fit` object referencing the `Dataset` and the fit function.
        
        The fit is performed by minimizing a function called B{FCN}, which is a measure of how well the
        fitted function matches the dataset for a given set of parameters. The default B{FCN} is a X{WSSR},
        (X{weighted sum of squared residuals}, also known as a S{chi}-square.
        
        An external B{FCN} can also be specified. A B{FCN} is a `Python` function with fixed argument
        structure: `FCN(dataset, fit_function, param_values)`. 
        
        @param fit_function: The function to fit to the dataset.
        @type fit_function: function
        
        @keyword external_fcn: A custom FCN. If missing, a S{chi}-square FCN will be assumed.
        @type external_fcn: function
        
        @return: A `Fit` object.
        '''
        
        if external_fcn is not None:
            return Fit(self, fit_function, external_fcn)
        else:
            return Fit(self, fit_function)
        
        
        

if __name__ == "__main__":

    def linear_2par(x, slope=1, x_offset=0):
        
        return slope * (x - x_offset)
    
    myXData = np.asarray([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
    myYData = np.asarray([2, 3.1, 4.2, 5.5, 7.23])
    
    tstFloat = 0.1
    tstArray = np.asarray([.1, .1, .2, .5, .8])
     
    myDataset = Dataset(xdata=myXData, 
                         ydata=myYData,
                         xabsstat=0.1,
                         xabssyst=0.1)

    print myDataset.get_formatted()
    
    myDataset.write_formatted('/home/daniel/tmp/23465.inp')
    myDataset = Dataset(input_file='/home/daniel/tmp/23465.inp')
    
    print myDataset.get_formatted()
